content: Investments Asked by Gabriel ThamAsked on 07 Feb 2019Is this strategy of combining options and ETF investing viable? I am doing ETF investing, buy world index and global bond index ETFs, DCA every few months. Can it work with options selling? Sell put options of a world index etf (e.g VT vanguard total world etf) and collect premiums while the price drops. If it hits the strike price, say $50, i will be glad to buy and own it.This kills 2 birds with 1 stone it seems because I am ok to buy the index etf at a lower price and i get to collect premiums while waiting.2 answersAnswerBump1

Grand MasterAnswered on 12 Sep 2019What you suggest on selling puts on stocks (ETF) that you want to own is known as Cash Secured Puts.It's my favourite options strategy. I love it.The only disadvantage is if you set a strike price it does not reach, and the stock keeps going up and up and up, you will forgo the major upsides that you could have gotten by buying the stock (ETF) outright.With this disadvantage, I still love option selling. It's a major source of trading income for me.Once I owned the stock, I will also start selling COVERED calls on it. Collect extra premiums while the stock goes down or sideways or go up but not too much...If it hits too much, great I get to sell at a profit plus premium collected.then I go back to cash-secured puts.0 comments1

Jonathan Chia Guangrong, Fund Manager at JCG FundLevel 6. MasterUpdated on 07 Jun 2019Options selling to gain premiums and the underlying counter is viable as long as you are comfortable with the chosen strike price and your account can support the margins. Do take note that each put option contract equals to one hundred shares of the underlying stock so in your example, you will need to set aside $50*100=$5000 to buy the shares for each option contract.Actually since you already own the underlying, why not consider selling covered calls instead? You will need 100 shares per contract to sell covered calls. Can collect additional premium on top of dividends. Do note that if exercised, your shares will be taken away.Personally I won't bother holding the stock since more premium can be collected with the same amount you use to buy stock (i.e more positions can be opened) 2 comments0

Jonathan Chia Guangrong07 Feb 2019You will usually want to sell covered calls at a higher strike price than current. So in a way you gain the premiums from selling the covered calls and the capital gain. Then can continue selling puts to get back the stock at a lower price. Rinse and repeat if so desired. Just highlighting another way to use options
